body:
To be honest i am super confused, probably because i have no nix(os) experience.
Are you saying that rust's `target/` folder is read-only in nixos? How can the app itself be compiled then?

Do you have any error logs from before the patch was applied?

Hi there! I actually wrote that patch. Basically the issue is that `/usr` does not exist and packages are built into and later run from an immutable directory like `/nix/store/[hash]-name` with exe installed to `/nix/store/[hash]-name/bin/exe` and resources installed to `/nix/store/[hash]-name/lib/cargo_name`

The assumptions in this code snippet do not hold for that layout because it assumes either `/usr` exists, `$APPDIR` is set in the environment, or that the path ends in `/data/usr/bin`: https://github.com/tauri-apps/tauri/blob/d70470f868511adb551afcd17acade6dd08b14da/core/tauri-utils/src/platform.rs#L253-L275

The [patch linked above](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/728e957b03d9194b7d277907cb1bc154081cf35a/pkgs/by-name/do/dorion/tauri-env-resource-dir.patch) basically adds an escape hatch so that any downstream which conforms to a filesystem hierarchy that is not one of those 3 options can use to override the resource directory (which that need is not Nix-specific and would occur elsewhere as well, like with AppImages which already had to be hardcoded)

Alternatively, if the code path could try to use `exe_dir.join(format!("../lib/{}", package_info.package_name()))` regardless of the path ending in `/data/usr/bin` or the existence of `/usr` (either as a fallback or as an initial check), that would also work for our and I imagine most any other downstreams

Thank you for the prompt response!

> Are you saying that rust's target/ folder is read-only in nixos? How can the app itself be compiled then?

Also just to be clear, this doesn't have to do with it. The target directory gets written to just fine, but when it does `cargo install` it gets put not in `/usr` and that is the part that Tauri trips up on

> To be honest i am super confused, probably because i have no nix(os) experience. Are you saying that rust's `target/` folder is read-only in nixos? How can the app itself be compiled then?
> 
> Do you have any error logs from before the patch was applied?

This should be an easy fix right?

issue.title: [bug] Resources are not found if Linux bundle is installed anywhere else other than /usr

labels.name: status: needs triage
labels.description: This issue needs to triage, applied to new issues

repository.name: tauri
repository.description: Build smaller, faster, and more secure desktop and mobile applications with a web frontend.

issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Relative paths to resources in Linux should resolve to the `../lib/<name>/` directory relative to the executable location, instead of assuming the executable is always in `/usr/lib/<name>/`.

This was fixed for AppImage bundle (#1308) by [looking for `$APPDIR` env var](https://github.com/tauri-apps/tauri/blob/1.x/core/tauri-utils/src/platform.rs#L179), and there's a "trick" to make it work when running from the deb bundle directory, by [checking whether it's running from `/data/usr/bin`](https://github.com/tauri-apps/tauri/blob/1.x/core/tauri-utils/src/platform.rs#L173). Otherwise, it is simply assumed that the application was installed in `/usr`, which is not necessarily true.

That trick of making it work from the bundle directory causes confusion, because if we try to run it from there after we build it, it appears that the application works from anywhere, but when it is actually placed somewhere else (like `/usr/local/` or `/opt`), resources are not found anymore.

It is work noting that, both for Windows and MacOS, the resource directory is resolved to a path relative to the executable. So, doing the same for Linux would be a simple change, and it could also work for the AppImage case without needing to special-case it, and of course, it would continue to work just as fine for standard bundle installations.

### Reproduction

* Create an application that accesses a resource file.
* Build the deb bundle.
* Copy the contents of the bundle data directory to somewhere else or unpack the deb file in a non-standard root.
* Run the application from the new location.

### Expected behavior

The application should find the resource file.

### Full `tauri info` output

```text
[✔] Environment
    - OS: Ubuntu 22.04 X64
    ✔ webkit2gtk-4.0: 2.42.5
    ✔ rsvg2: 2.52.5
    ✔ rustc: 1.76.0 (07dca489a 2024-02-04)
    ✔ cargo: 1.76.0 (c84b36747 2024-01-18)
    ✔ rustup: 1.26.0 (5af9b9484 2023-04-05)
    ✔ Rust toolchain: stable-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu (default)
    - node: 20.11.1
    - yarn: 1.22.21
    - npm: 10.2.4

[-] Packages
    - tauri [RUST]: 1.6.0
    - tauri-build [RUST]: 1.5.1
    - wry [RUST]: 0.24.7
    - tao [RUST]: 0.16.7
    - @tauri-apps/api [NPM]: 1.5.3
    - @tauri-apps/cli [NPM]: 1.5.10

[-] App
    - build-type: bundle
    - CSP: unset
    - distDir: ../dist
    - devPath: http://localhost:1420/
    - framework: React
    - bundler: Vite
```


### Stack trace

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

issue.title: cargo-tauri.hook: init

labels.name: 6.topic: nixos
labels.description: Issues or PRs affecting NixOS modules, or package usability issues specific to NixOS

labels.name: 8.has: documentation
labels.description: This PR adds or changes documentation

labels.name: 8.has: changelog
labels.description: This PR adds or changes release notes

labels.name: 10.rebuild-linux: 11-100
labels.description: This PR causes between 11 and 100 packages to rebuild on Linux.

labels.name: 10.rebuild-darwin: 1-10
labels.description: This PR causes between 1 and 10 packages to rebuild on Darwin.

issue.body:
## Description of changes With Tauri apps getting more popular and added to nixpkgs, I believe it's time we share the tedious setup required to build them. This PR introduces a new hook in `cargo-tauri.hook` that builds on top of `rustPlatform.buildRustPackage` (or more acurately, its hooks) to leverage Tauri's bundling feature in creating packages. It is compatible with the two primary targets we share with Tauri -- Linux and macOS -- and meant to be used alongside pre-existing tools for package managers such as npm, pnpm, and yarn Supersedes #318117 CC @doronbehar for changes made to `yarnConfigHook` ## Things done - Built on platform(s) - [x] x86_64-linux - [ ] aarch64-linux - [ ] x86_64-darwin - [ ] aarch64-darwin - For non-Linux: Is sandboxing enabled in `nix.conf`? (See [Nix manual](https://nixos.org/manual/nix/stable/command-ref/conf-file.html)) - [ ] `sandbox = relaxed` - [ ] `sandbox = true` - [x] Tested, as applicable: - [NixOS test(s)](https://nixos.org/manual/nixos/unstable/index.html#sec-nixos-tests) (look inside [nixos/tests](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/master/nixos/tests)) - and/or [package tests](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/master/pkgs/README.md#package-tests) - or, for functions and "core" functionality, tests in [lib/tests](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/master/lib/tests) or [pkgs/test](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/master/pkgs/test) - made sure NixOS tests are [linked](https://nixos.org/manual/nixpkgs/unstable/#ssec-nixos-tests-linking) to the relevant packages - [x] Tested compilation of all packages that depend on this change using `nix-shell -p nixpkgs-review --run "nixpkgs-review rev HEAD"`. Note: all changes have to be committed, also see [nixpkgs-review usage](https://github.com/Mic92/nixpkgs-review#usage) - [x] Tested basic functionality of all binary files (usually in `./result/bin/`) - [24.11 Release Notes](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/master/nixos/doc/manual/release-notes/rl-2411.section.md) (or backporting [23.11](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/master/nixos/doc/manual/release-notes/rl-2311.section.md) and [24.05](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/master/nixos/doc/manual/release-notes/rl-2405.section.md) Release notes) - [x] (Package updates) Added a release notes entry if the change is major or breaking - [ ] (Module updates) Added a release notes entry if the change is significant - [ ] (Module addition) Added a release notes entry if adding a new NixOS module - [x] Fits [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md). --- Result of `nixpkgs-review` run on x86_64-linux [1](https://github.com/Mic92/nixpkgs-review)

issue.title: feat: allow overriding resource directory at compile-time

repository.name: tauri
repository.description: Build smaller, faster, and more secure desktop and mobile applications with a web frontend.

issue.body:
<!--
Before submitting a PR, please read https://github.com/tauri-apps/tauri/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines

1. Give the PR a descriptive title.

  Examples of good title:
    - fix(windows): fix race condition in event loop
    - docs: update example for `App::show`
    - feat: add `Window::set_fullscreen`

  Examples of bad title:
    - fix #7123
    - update docs
    - fix bugs

2. If there is a related issue, reference it in the PR text, e.g. closes #123.
3. If this change requires a new version, then add a change file in `.changes` directory with the appropriate bump, see https://github.com/tauri-apps/tauri/blob/dev/.changes/README.md
4. Ensure that all your commits are signed https://docs.github.com/en/authentication/managing-commit-signature-verification/signing-commits
5. Ensure `cargo test` and `cargo clippy` passes.
6. Propose your changes as a draft PR if your work is still in progress.
-->

closes #8679
